Agent Shepherd Installation & Distribution Refactor
description: Refactor Agent Shepherd's installation and distribution system to support hybrid installations, cross-platform compatibility, and user-friendly installer scripts. This includes creating installer scripts for macOS/Linux and Windows, adding update/version commands, and implementing README symlink for GitHub visibility.
design:
Agent Shepherd - Installation & Distribution Refactor
Session Summary
The Problem
Agent Shepherd lives in .agent-shepherd/ by design - when installed in user projects, it should be a clean, self-contained dotfolder that doesn't pollute the user's repo. However, this creates a GitHub visibility problem: the README at .agent-shepherd/README.md is hidden because GitHub only shows READMEs at the repository root.
We explored several solutions:
- Moving everything to repo root (rejected - would conflict with user's files when installed)
- Two separate repos (rejected - unnecessary complexity)
- Symlink + smart installer (chosen solution)
The Solution
1. Symlink for GitHub visibility: Create README.md at repo root as a symlink to .agent-shepherd/README.md. GitHub renders symlinked READMEs, so visitors see the full documentation. The symlink is only in the development repo - users never get it.
2. Smart installer: Instead of users cloning the whole repo, they run an installer script that copies ONLY .agent-shepherd/ to their project. This means:
   - Users get a clean installation (just the dotfolder)
   - No README conflict with their own project
   - No dev files (openspec/, .beads/, etc.) polluting their repo
3. Hybrid installation model: Users choose between:
   - Hybrid: Binary in ~/.agent-shepherd/, config per-project in ./.agent-shepherd/config/
   - Local: Everything self-contained in ./.agent-shepherd/
4. Command linking options: Users choose whether to:
   - Global link: ashep command available everywhere (convenient, single version)
   - No link: Run via bunx ashep or explicit path (supports multiple versions)
5. Versioning via GitHub releases: Tags like v1.0.0 enable:
   - Installing specific versions
   - ashep update / ashep update v1.2.0 for upgrades/downgrades
   - Version tracking in ~/.agent-shepherd/VERSION
6. Cross-platform support: Two installers (bash + PowerShell) plus fixes to the codebase to replace Unix-specific commands with Node APIs.
Why This Approach?
| Decision | Why |
|----------|-----|
| Symlink README | Single source of truth, visible on GitHub, not shipped to users |
| Installer script | Users get only what they need, clean project |
| Hybrid option | Shared binary saves disk space, per-project config makes sense |
| Local option | Self-contained projects that work when cloned |
| Dual installers | Windows and macOS/Linux have different shells |
| ashep update | Easy maintenance, version pinning for stability |
Current Windows Compatibility Issues
The codebase has Unix-specific commands that break on Windows:
- cp -r → needs fs.cpSync()
- rm -rf → needs fs.rmSync()
- $HOME → needs os.homedir()
- curl | bash for Beads install → needs OS detection
---
Implementation Plan
Phase 1: Cross-Platform Fixes
Goal: Make current code work on Windows
File: .agent-shepherd/src/cli/index.ts
1. Add imports:
import { cpSync, rmSync } from "fs";
import { homedir, platform } from "os";
2. Replace shell commands:
   - Line 667: execSync(\cp -r ...\`) → cpSync(source, dest, { recursive: true })`
   - Line 755: execSync(\rm -rf ...\`) → rmSync(path, { recursive: true, force: true })`
   - Line 792: process.env.HOME → homedir()
3. OS-aware Beads installation in quickstart:
if (platform() === "win32") {
  console.log("Please install Beads manually: https://get.beads.dev");
} else {
  execSync("curl -fsSL https://get.beads.dev | bash", { stdio: "inherit" });
}
---
Phase 2: Hybrid Installation Support
Goal: Support global install + local config
File: .agent-shepherd/src/core/path-utils.ts
Replace current implementation with:
import { existsSync } from "fs";
import { join, dirname } from "path";
import { homedir } from "os";
export function getGlobalInstallDir(): string {
  return join(homedir(), ".agent-shepherd");
}
export function findLocalAgentShepherdDir(): string | null {
  let currentDir = process.cwd();
  while (true) {
    const agentShepherdDir = join(currentDir, ".agent-shepherd");
    if (existsSync(agentShepherdDir)) {
      return agentShepherdDir;
    }
    const parentDir = dirname(currentDir);
    if (parentDir === currentDir) break;
    currentDir = parentDir;
  }
  return null;
}
export function findInstallDir(): string {
  // Check for local full install (has src/)
  const local = findLocalAgentShepherdDir();
  if (local && existsSync(join(local, "src"))) {
    return local;
  }
  // Fall back to global
  const global = getGlobalInstallDir();
  if (existsSync(global)) {
    return global;
  }
  throw new Error("Agent Shepherd not installed. Run the installer or 'ashep init'");
}
export function findConfigDir(): string {
  // Check for local config
  const local = findLocalAgentShepherdDir();
  if (local && existsSync(join(local, "config"))) {
    return join(local, "config");
  }
  // Fall back to global config
  const global = getGlobalInstallDir();
  const globalConfig = join(global, "config");
  if (existsSync(globalConfig)) {
    return globalConfig;
  }
  throw new Error("No configuration found. Run 'ashep init' in your project.");
}
export function findPluginsDir(): string {
  const local = findLocalAgentShepherdDir();
  if (local && existsSync(join(local, "plugins"))) {
    return join(local, "plugins");
  }
  const global = getGlobalInstallDir();
  return join(global, "plugins");
}
// Legacy function - backward compatibility
export function findAgentShepherdDir(): string {
  const local = findLocalAgentShepherdDir();
  if (local) return local;
  const global = getGlobalInstallDir();
  if (existsSync(global)) return global;
  throw new Error(".agent-shepherd directory not found. Run the installer or 'ashep init'");
}

Phase 3: Installer Scripts
Goal: Create platform-specific installers
File: .agent-shepherd/install.sh (macOS/Linux)
#!/bin/bash
set -e
VERSION="${1:-latest}"
REPO_URL="https://github.com/USER/agent-shepherd.git"
echo "Agent Shepherd Installer"
echo "========================"
echo ""
echo "1. Where should Agent Shepherd be installed?"
echo ""
echo "   [H] Hybrid (recommended)"
echo "       Binary: ~/.agent-shepherd/"
echo "       Config: per-project (./.agent-shepherd/config/)"
echo ""
echo "   [L] Local (self-contained)"
echo "       Everything: ./.agent-shepherd/"
echo ""
read -p "> " INSTALL_MODE
if [[ "$INSTALL_MODE" =~ ^[Ll]$ ]]; then
  INSTALL_DIR="$(pwd)/.agent-shepherd"
  echo "Installing locally to: $INSTALL_DIR"
else
  INSTALL_DIR="$HOME/.agent-shepherd"
  echo "Installing globally to: $INSTALL_DIR"
fi
echo ""
echo "2. How do you want to run 'ashep'?"
echo ""
echo "   [G] Global link (recommended)"
echo "       Run 'ashep' from anywhere"
echo ""
echo "   [N] No global link"
echo "       Run via: bunx ashep"
echo ""
read -p "> " LINK_MODE
# Clone to temp
TEMP_DIR=$(mktemp -d)
echo ""
echo "Downloading Agent Shepherd${VERSION:+ $VERSION}..."
if [ "$VERSION" = "latest" ]; then
  git clone --depth 1 "$REPO_URL" "$TEMP_DIR" 2>/dev/null
else
  git clone --depth 1 --branch "$VERSION" "$REPO_URL" "$TEMP_DIR" 2>/dev/null
fi
# Backup existing config/plugins if upgrading
if [ -d "$INSTALL_DIR/config" ]; then
  echo "Backing up existing config..."
  cp -r "$INSTALL_DIR/config" "$TEMP_DIR/config-backup"
fi
if [ -d "$INSTALL_DIR/plugins" ]; then
  echo "Backing up existing plugins..."
  cp -r "$INSTALL_DIR/plugins" "$TEMP_DIR/plugins-backup"
fi
# Remove old installation (preserve config/plugins/logs)
if [ -d "$INSTALL_DIR" ]; then
  find "$INSTALL_DIR" -mindepth 1 -maxdepth 1 \
    ! -name 'config' ! -name 'plugins' ! -name 'logs' \
    -exec rm -rf {} +
fi
# Copy new installation
mkdir -p "$INSTALL_DIR"
cp -r "$TEMP_DIR/.agent-shepherd/"* "$INSTALL_DIR/"
# Restore backups
[ -d "$TEMP_DIR/config-backup" ] && cp -r "$TEMP_DIR/config-backup" "$INSTALL_DIR/config"
[ -d "$TEMP_DIR/plugins-backup" ] && cp -r "$TEMP_DIR/plugins-backup" "$INSTALL_DIR/plugins"
# Store version
echo "$VERSION" > "$INSTALL_DIR/VERSION"
# Install dependencies
echo "Installing dependencies..."
cd "$INSTALL_DIR"
bun install
# Link globally if requested
if [[ "$LINK_MODE" =~ ^[Gg]$ ]]; then
  echo "Linking ashep command globally..."
  bun link
fi
# Cleanup
rm -rf "$TEMP_DIR"
echo ""
echo "✅ Agent Shepherd installed!"
echo ""
if [[ ! "$INSTALL_MODE" =~ ^[Ll]$ ]]; then
  echo "Run 'ashep init' in your project to create local config."
fi

title: Agent Shepherd Fallback Agent System Implementation
description:
Problem Statement
When running ashep quickstart, validation fails because policies require capabilities (testing, qa, review, architecture) that don't exist in synced OpenCode agents. This prevents new users from getting started immediately.

Solution: Cascading Fallback Agent Hierarchy
A three-tier fallback system that allows capabilities to map to existing real agents in OpenCode:
Phase-Level (specific) → Policy-Level (policy-wide) → Global-Level (system-wide)

Key concept: When a policy requires a capability that no agent has, the system falls back to a specified agent (e.g., build) to handle the task anyway.

Design Decisions Confirmed
1. Configuration Structure
config.yaml (Global Level):
fallback:
  enabled: true              # Master switch - if false, NO fallback anywhere
  default_agent: build       # Default fallback agent for all capabilities
  mappings:                 # Optional: global capability-specific mappings
    review: summary
    documentation: summary
    architecture: plan

policies.yaml (Policy and Phase Levels):
policies:
  simple:
    fallback_enabled: true        # Inherits from global if not set
    fallback_agent: build        # Inherits from global if not set
    fallback_mappings:           # Optional: policy-specific mappings
      review: summary
    phases:
      - name: test
        capabilities: [testing]
        # Phase-level override:
        fallback_agent: general
        # OR disable for this phase:
        fallback_enabled: false

2. Hierarchy Rules
- Cascading: Phase-level overrides Policy-level overrides Global-level
- Default inheritance: If a level doesn't specify settings, inherit from higher level
- Disable: If fallback_enabled: false at any level, fallback is disabled for that level
- Master switch: If config.fallback.enabled: false, NO fallback anywhere

3. Mappings Explained
mappings allows capability-specific fallback agents:
- Without mappings: All missing capabilities use default_agent: build
- With mappings: Specific capabilities use different agents:
  - review: summary → Review tasks handled by summary agent
  - architecture: plan → Architecture tasks handled by plan agent
  - Everything else → Falls back to build
Why mappings?
- Better agent matching for different work types
- summary agent is better at review/documentation than build agent
- plan agent is better at architecture than build agent
- Still provides default fallback for anything else

4. Confirmed Defaults
- Default fallback agent: build (has: coding, refactoring, building)
- Default enabled state: true (turned on for both config and policies)
- Default mappings: Keep simple initially - only default_agent: build (users can add mappings later)
- Backward compatibility: Treat as disabled if config doesn't have fallback fields

5. Runtime Behavior
Agent Selection Logic:
function selectAgent(capability, policy, phase) {
  // 1. Try to find agent with capability
  let agent = getAgentsByCapability(capability);
  
  if (!agent) {
    // 2. No agent has capability - use fallback
    agent = getFallbackAgent(capability, policy, phase);
    
    if (agent) {
      logger.info(`ℹ️ Using fallback agent '${agent.name}' for capability '${capability}'`);
    }
  }
  
  return agent;
}

function getFallbackAgent(capability, policy, phase) {
  // Check cascading hierarchy:
  // 1. Phase-level override?
  if (phase.fallback_agent) return getAgent(phase.fallback_agent);
  
  // 2. Phase disabled?
  if (phase.fallback_enabled === false) return null;
  
  // 3. Policy mappings?
  if (policy.fallback_mappings?.[capability]) return getAgent(policy.fallback_mappings[capability]);
  
  // 4. Policy disabled?
  if (policy.fallback_enabled === false) return null;
  
  // 5. Global mappings?
  if (config.fallback?.mappings?.[capability]) return getAgent(config.fallback.mappings[capability]);
  
  // 6. Global disabled?
  if (!config.fallback?.enabled) return null;
  
  // 7. Use policy or global default_agent
  const fallbackId = policy.fallback_agent || config.fallback?.default_agent;
  return fallbackId ? getAgent(fallbackId) : null;
}

6. Validation Updates
Validator must:
1. Check if fallback agents exist in OpenCode for all 3 levels
2. Verify fallback agents are active
3. Show info messages about which capabilities will use fallback
4. Error if fallback enabled but agent doesn't exist or is inactive
5. Pass validation when fallback covers missing capabilities

Example validation output:
✅ Main configuration: Valid
✅ Policy definitions: Valid
✅ Agent registry: Valid
ℹ️  Policy chain validation: Using fallback for 2 capabilities
   • policies.yaml: default.test: Capability 'testing' handled by fallback agent 'Build Agent'
   • policies.yaml: default.review: Capability 'review' handled by fallback agent 'Summary Agent'
✅ Policy chain validation: Valid

Implementation Plan
Phase 1: Schema Updates
1. Update config.schema.json:
   - Add fallback object schema
   - Include enabled (boolean), default_agent (string), mappings (object)
   - Mark as optional for backward compatibility
2. Update policies.schema.json:
   - Add fallback_enabled (boolean, optional) to policy level
   - Add fallback_agent (string, optional) to policy level
   - Add fallback_mappings (object, optional) to policy level
   - Add fallback_agent (string, optional) to phase level
   - Add fallback_enabled (boolean, optional) to phase level

Phase 2: Configuration Loading
3. Update config.ts:
   - Load and parse fallback section from config.yaml
   - Provide default values (enabled: false, no mappings) if not present
4. Update policy.ts:
   - Parse fallback fields when loading policies
   - Handle inheritance logic (policy inherits from global if not set)

Phase 3: Validation
5. Update policy-capability-validator.ts:
   - Modify validateCapability() to check fallback hierarchy
   - Add new validation function validateFallbackAgent()
   - Update error messages to include fallback information
   - Change severity: missing capability with valid fallback = info/warning (not error)
   - Add error type for invalid fallback config (agent doesn't exist or inactive)

Phase 4: Runtime Selection
6. Update agent-registry.ts:
   - Add getFallbackAgent(capability, policy, phase) function
   - Integrate with selectAgent() to use fallback when needed
   - Add logging when fallback is used

Phase 5: CLI Updates
7. Update cmdInit() in cli/index.ts:
   - Add fallback section to default config.yaml:
          fallback:
       enabled: true
       default_agent: build
     
8. Update cmdQuickstart() in cli/index.ts:
   - Add explanation about fallback system
   - Show which capabilities are using fallback
   - Make it clear this is normal for first-time setup
9. Update validation output in cmdValidatePolicyChain():
   - Show fallback info clearly
   - Distinguish between critical errors (no agent, no fallback) and fallback usage

Phase 6: Documentation
10. Update README.md:
    - Add section explaining fallback system
    - Include configuration examples
    - Explain when and why to use fallback
11. Update docs/config-config.md:
    - Document fallback configuration section
    - Provide examples of global and policy-level mappings
    - Explain master switch behavior
12. Update docs/policies-config.md:
    - Document fallback fields at policy and phase level
    - Show cascading hierarchy examples
    - Explain disable functionality
13. Update docs/architecture.md (if applicable):
    - Explain fallback system in architecture overview
    - Add fallback to workflow diagrams

Testing Checklist
- [ ] Schema validation accepts fallback configurations
- [ ] Fallback disabled when not present in config (backward compatibility)
- [ ] Global fallback works for all missing capabilities
- [ ] Policy-level fallback overrides global
- [ ] Phase-level fallback overrides policy and global
- [ ] fallback_enabled: false disables fallback at that level
- [ ] config.fallback.enabled: false disables all fallbacks
- [ ] Validation passes when fallback covers missing capabilities
- [ ] Validation errors when fallback agent doesn't exist
- [ ] Validation errors when fallback agent is inactive
- [ ] Runtime uses fallback agent when capability missing
- [ ] Runtime logs when fallback is used
- [ ] Mappings route capabilities to correct agents
- [ ] Default configuration creates working system after quickstart

3. Example content structure:
```markdown
## Fallback Agent System

When a policy requires a capability that no agent has, the fallback system allows
you to specify a default agent to handle the task anyway. This is especially useful
for getting started quickly with default agents.

### When to Use Fallback

- **First-time setup**: Get started immediately with default agents
- **Testing workflows**: Test workflows before adding specialized agents
- **Limited agent pool**: Use available agents for all capability requirements

### Basic Configuration

Add to `.agent-shepherd/config/config.yaml`:

```yaml
fallback:
  enabled: true
  default_agent: build
```

### Cascading Hierarchy

The fallback system works on three levels:

1. **Global Level** (config.yaml): System-wide default
2. **Policy Level** (policies.yaml): Policy-specific override
3. **Phase Level** (policies.yaml): Phase-specific override

Each level can override the levels above it.

### Advanced Configuration

Use capability-specific mappings for better agent matching:

```yaml
fallback:
  enabled: true
  default_agent: build
  mappings:
    review: summary
    architecture: plan
    documentation: summary
```

See [docs/config-config.md](docs/config-config.md) for detailed configuration options.
```

title: Build Agent Shepherd Orchestration System
description:
The current agent ecosystem lacks effective orchestration for multi-step workflows, policy enforcement, and human-in-the-loop coordination. Agent Shepherd fills this gap by providing a production-ready TypeScript/Bun project that orchestrates AI coding agents across Beads issues, using OpenCode as the execution environment, enabling safe, explainable, and autonomous software development.

**Reference Documentation**: See @urls.md for authoritative links to Beads, OpenCode, OpenSpec, BMAD Method, ReactFlow, and architectural inspiration from Steve Yegge's articles on agent autonomy and multi-step development.

- Implement Worker Engine to pull from Beads and launch agents in OpenCode sessions
- Add Monitor Engine for supervision, timeout detection, and HITL handling
- Create Policy Engine for workflow phase transitions and retries
- Build Agent Registry with capability-based agent selection
- Integrate logging with JSONL and SQLite dual storage like Beads
- Add OpenCode integration using @opencode-ai/sdk for session management
- Implement Beads integration via shell commands for issue management
- Develop minimal ReactFlow-based UI for flow visualization
- Include installer and init commands with default configs
